For a typical solar-type star as a source and a red giant as a lens,  the flux-contrast due to image eclipsing on the overall flux of source and lens would be in the order of $10^{-5}$. Fortunately in recent years, with developing telescope defocusing method, we can reach to the photometric precision in the order of milli-magnitude. This method, recently has been used for transit observation of extrasolar planets that dims the flux of parent star \citep{south}.
